newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek rates hold, bond profit taking in late trade.
newsitem.headline: Greek rates hold, bond profit taking in late trade.

text.p: Secondary bond market activity picked up steam on Wednesday with domestic and foreign players raking in profits but money rates were unmoved and ecu/drachma was holding despite sales of 100 million ecus at the fixing, dealers said.
A foreign bank also sold 9.0 billion yens for drachmas at the fixing. A yen-denominated loan for state railways organisation (OSE) accounted for the sum, dealers said.

"There was a lot of trading activity in bonds today with some players taking profits on older FRNs," said a state bank trader. "Local and foreign investors kept on selling FRNs with short maturities and strips to get into newly auctioned ones."
Money dealers said depos and forex forwards were little changed in late dealings on light to moderate trading volume.
The central bank injected overnight funds at an unchanged 13.40 percent.

"It looks as if the central bank is following a different interest rate policy from the finance ministry that cuts rates on its debt paper aggressively," said a dealer. "This policy does not bode well for the market."
The mark was quoted at 157.00/10 drachmas from Wednesday's 157.070 fix, the dollar at 244.81/91 drachmas from 245.120 and the Ecu at 303.55/65 from 303.750 drachmas.
The National Bank of Greece, the domestic money market's biggest player, quoted the following late rates:
